The beliefs of childcare professionals.

questions.question: How has children's health in the United States changes since the 19th century?

choices.answer: Today's children get plenty of exersize
Children no longer lack food to nourish them.
Overweight and obesity is not longer a problem.
Many previously deadly diseases can be prevented or cured.

questions.question: How has child's play changed since the 19th century?

choices.answer: Children today have a greater variety of toys.
It is more important than it used to be.
It is not as important as it used to be.
Today's children spend less of their time playing.

questions.question: What is the benefit of stimulating a baby's senses?

choices.answer: It will help the baby walk earlier.
It will help develop the baby's brain.
It will help the baby sleep better.
It will calm the baby's digestive system.

questions.question: How does a child repeating the same action over and over affect him or her?

choices.answer: It will cause the chid to become bored or cranky.
It will reinforce the action so it becomes easier to do.
It will limit the child's mental development.
It will cause a repetitive injury.

questions.question: What is not one of the general rules of child development?

choices.answer: Development proceeds at an individual rate.
Development is similar for each individual.
Development stops at the teenage years.
Development builds on prior learning.

questions.question: Factors influencing development fall into what two categories?

choices.answer: Heredity and Coincidence
Blood type and geography
Heredity and Environment
The economy and the environment.

questions.question: What is not true about self-esteem?

choices.answer: Children with high self-esteem are more likely to make friends.
The level of self-esteem formed as a child is unlikely to change over time.
Children with low self-esteem are less likely to make healthy choices.
Children with high self-esteem tend to under perform in school.

questions.question: Why is it useful to observe children?

choices.answer: It allows you to shape their personalities.
It makes caring for them more interesting.
It allows you to spot disabilities or additional needs they may have.
Being observed makes children try harder.
